entries.meaning: The study of the humanities or the liberal arts; literary (especially classical) scholarship. [from 19th c.]

(historical, often capitalized) Specifically, a cultural and intellectual movement in 14th-16th century Europe characterised by attention to classical culture and a promotion of vernacular texts, notably during the Renaissance. [from 19th c.]
examples: There were good reasons for humanism and the Renaissance to take their origins from fourteenth-century Italy.

entries.meaning: An ethical system that centers on humans and their values, needs, interests, abilities, dignity and freedom; especially used for a secular one which rejects theistic religion and superstition. [from 19th c.]
